title: Ming Yang
text:
My Journey

2025: Micron Technology, Inc | MOD SSD Defect Data Visualization Intern
2021: AiDA Technologies | Database Engineer Intern

title: Project: IoT Plant Watering System
text:
This group project developed a smart plant irrigation system using Raspberry Pi and sensors to automate watering based on soil moisture levels. It features a 3D-printed water dispensing tube, a mini motor for valve control, and a web dashboard for remote access.



Project Poster

title: Project: IoT Plant Watering System
text:
This group project developed a smart plant irrigation system using Raspberry Pi and sensors to automate watering based on soil moisture levels. It features a 3D-printed water dispensing tube, a mini motor for valve control, and a web dashboard for remote access.



Project Poster

title: Project: IoT Plant Watering System
text:
Technologies Used

Hardware: Raspberry Pi, Hardware Sensors/Servo, 3D Printed Parts
Software: Python, MQTT, SQLite
Database: SQLite for logging moisture and valve states

title: Project: IoT Plant Watering System
text:
Key Features

Moisture Monitoring: Real-time soil moisture readings via sensor trigger automatic watering.
Water Level Detection: Alerts when the reservoir is low.
Manual Override: Remote control to open/close valves via a web dashboard.
MQTT Integration: Publishes sensor data and receives control commands seamlessly.

title: Project: IoT Plant Watering System
text:
Key Learnings

Hardware-Software Integration: Interfaced sensors and actuators with Raspberry Pi for real-time control.
IoT Scalability: Designed a system that is small yet expandable using MQTT for remote monitoring.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text: For this assessment, I utilized Generative AI tools like ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot to assist in the development of my portfolio website.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text: For this assessment, I utilized Generative AI tools like ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot to assist in the development of my portfolio website.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
How GenAI Helped

Code Structure: I used GenAI to generate the initial HTML boilerplate and CSS for the responsive grid layouts used in my work_*.html pages.
Debugging: When my JavaScript for the “Gwent” game logic had issues with the turn-based state machine, I pasted the error logs into ChatGPT, which suggested fixes for the asynchronous function calls.
Content Refinement: GenAI helped refine my project descriptions to be more punchy and professional, ensuring my “Key Learnings” sections were concise.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
Benefits

Efficiency: It significantly sped up the coding process, allowing me to focus on the design and content rather than syntax errors.
Learning Aid: It acted as a tutor, explaining why certain CSS properties (like flexbox vs grid) worked better for my specific layout needs.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
Challenges

Context Awareness: The AI sometimes provided generic code that didn’t fit my specific file structure, requiring me to manually adjust paths and class names.
Over-reliance: There is a temptation to copy-paste without fully understanding the underlying logic, which I had to actively mitigate by reviewing every line of suggested code.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
Future Application
I see GenAI as a “force multiplier” for my future career in Fintech. It will allow me to prototype applications faster and write unit tests more comprehensively, but the core architectural decisions will still rely on my own domain knowledge.

title: Data Visualization
text:
During my internship at Micron Technology, I completed visualizations for inspection machines, helping to identify defect patterns in SSD manufacturing.


The goal was to allow better conceptualization of defect data through graphical representations. I used Tableau and Python to create interactive dashboards that communicated insights effectively to engineers and managers globally.



We needed to move beyond raw data logs to understand when and where defects were occurring. - Temporal Patterns: I used line and area charts to show defect trends over time. - Composition: Pie and stacked bar charts were used to show the breakdown of defect types. - Distribution: Histograms helped visualize the distribution of defect occurrences across different manufacturing sites.



The visualizations allowed for quicker identification of machine faults, saving the company approximately ~$250k monthly on software subscriptions by consolidating analysis tools.



Visualization Example
